awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: INSITE:  INtegrating STEM Into Transition Education for Incarcerated Learners
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will investigate the impact of a Universal Design for Learning (UDL) App-based curriculum on STEM career knowledge, interests, competencies, and readiness for incarcerated youth. Integrating STEM into Transition Education for Incarcerated Learners (INSITE) will integrate STEM workforce development activities into Merging Worlds, an empirically supported transition program, and deliver it through a UDL App-based framework to prepare and support STEM career readiness and employment for incarcerated youth age 14-19. INSITE will utilize a Design-based Research approach to (1) co-design the INSITE curriculum with incarcerated learners, juvenile justice educators, and STEM employers, and (2) test the impact of the curriculum on STEM employment outcomes.  The INSITE curriculum will be grounded in evidence-based research on incarcerated youth, STEM education, transition, recidivism, and workforce development. The curriculum will prepare and support career readiness that mediates the impact of limited access, exposure, and skill development for an untapped STEM workforce with vast potential.

The Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT) will serve as the theoretical framework to guide the research activities supporting the INSITE curriculum development. The rationale is that the theory allows for the contextual affordances and barriers that can influence individuals' career choices and actions. The research questions are (1) How prepared are incarcerated learners to transition to the STEM workforce? (2) What types of STEM workforce outcomes are incarcerated learners experiencing post-release? (3) What are the functional components of a STEM transition curriculum? (4) In what ways does the INSITE curriculum impact STEM career readiness and career actions of incarcerated youth? and (5) What are the roles of contextual variables and cognitive variables on STEM career readiness and career actions for incarcerated youth?  Data will be collected in iterative design and test phases that employ longitudinal, quasi-experimental, and qualitative case studies. INSITE will produce products across six topics aligned with the research questions and associated research plan. The findings are expected to document the impact of a novel intervention that prepares an underserved population for the STEM workforce.

The project is funded by the EHR Core Research program that supports fundamental STEM education research that focuses on STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project INSITE has generated significant outcomes and findings that have intellectual merit and broader impacts in the areas of STEM education for incarcerated youth. The intellectual merit of the project is evident through its rigorous research design, the application of the Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT), and the development of innovative curriculum components. INSITE is research-based, integrating STEM career components from a previous NSF-funded project into the Merging Two Worlds transition curriculum designed specifically for incarcerated youth. The iterative design process employed ongoing feedback from stakeholders, ensuring the relevance and effectiveness of the curriculum. The application of Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT) to marginalized populations of learners enriches the theoretical framework guiding the research activities. This application enhances the understanding of contextual factors influencing STEM career development for incarcerated youth, contributing intellectually to the field of career development and STEM education. The STEM Employer Needs Assessment conducted by INSITE is also a significant intellectual contribution. By gathering data from local employers and conducting follow-up interviews, the project identified critical skills, work experiences, and specific products desired by STEM employers. This information informs curriculum development, aligning it with the needs of the industry and increasing the relevance of STEM education for incarcerated youth. Furthermore, the development of a STEM assessment tool, evaluating STEM career interest, STEM competencies, and outcome expectations, showcases intellectual rigor. The intervention study, employing a mixed-method design, provides valuable insights into the impact of INSITE on STEM career interest and readiness outcomes. Finally, the ongoing analysis of data, including pre/post assessments and E-portfolio rubrics, contributes to the scholarly understanding of effective STEM interventions for marginalized learners.

The broader impacts of INSITE extend to diverse stakeholders, including incarcerated learners, juvenile justice educators, STEM employers, and society at large. INSITE has a profound impact on incarcerated learners by providing targeted STEM transition programming. The tablet-based personalized learning environment facilitates STEM instruction in a Universal Design for Learning (UDL) framework. The curriculum addresses the critical need for incarcerated students to attain technological, scientific, and mathematical literacy necessary for STEM employment. Furthermore, INSITE significantly contributes to the broader impact of enhancing teacher capacity. Through training and professional development, teachers gain the skills to create a tablet-based personalized learning environment, promoting students’ STEM career exploration and competencies. This capacity-building effort has the potential to influence not only the immediate educational environment but also contribute to internal systems changes in juvenile justice facilities nationally. Additionally, INSITE fosters collaboration with STEM employers, both virtually and in person. By involving employers in activities such as STEM job talks, fairs, and mock interviews, the project aims to change perceptions of incarcerated learners and build a new population of prospective STEM employees. This collaboration has broader societal implications by potentially increasing partnerships between academia, juvenile justice, and industry. The broader impact of INSITE extends to community stakeholders, employers, and society. The dissemination of data, content, and results through various channels, including conferences, webinars, and professional development sessions, ensures that the project's findings reach a wide audience. The potential societal impact includes improving post-secondary, unemployment, underemployment, socio-economic, homeless, and recidivism rates among previously incarcerated youth.

In summary, Project INSITE demonstrates both intellectual merit and broader impacts by advancing the understanding of STEM education for incarcerated youth, contributing to curriculum development, and fostering collaboration between academia, juvenile justice, and STEM industries. The project's outcomes have the potential to positively influence the educational experiences and future career trajectories of marginalized learners while addressing critical societal challenges.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2023
Modified by: Heather Griller Clark
